extractions.description: The paper explores two large acoustic pretrained models, ECAPA-TDNN and Wav2Vec 2.0/XLSR, for the task of accent classification in multiple languages. The authors provide a detailed recipe for using these models with the SpeechBrain toolkit and introduce a new benchmark dataset, CommonAccent, derived from the Common Voice dataset. The results indicate strong performance in accent classification, particularly with the Wav2Vec 2.0/XLSR model.

title.value: CommonAccent: Exploring Large Acoustic Pretrained Models for Accent Classification Based on Common Voice
title.justification: The title accurately reflects the main focus of the paper, which is exploring large acoustic pretrained models for accent classification based on the Common Voice dataset.
title.quote: CommonAccent: Exploring Large Acoustic Pretrained Models for Accent Classification Based on Common Voice

type.justification: The paper involves conducting experiments to fine-tune existing models and assess their performance on the task of accent classification, which is characteristic of an empirical study.
type.quote: In this paper, we study the accent classification problem, which is a critical building block towards accent-aware ASR.

research_field.justification: The paper deals with the processing and classification of speech data, with a specific focus on recognizing accented speech.
research_field.quote: Despite the recent advancements in Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), the recognition of accented speech still remains a dominant problem.

sub_research_field.justification: The specific focus of the research is on classifying different accents within the speech data.
sub_research_field.quote: We address multilingual accent classification through the ECAPA-TDNN and Wav2Vec 2.0/XLSR architectures.

name.justification: The ECAPA-TDNN model is used as one of the primary models for accent classification in this study.
name.quote: We address multilingual accent classification through the ECAPA-TDNN and Wav2Vec 2.0/XLSR architectures.

type.justification: ECAPA-TDNN is fundamentally an acoustic model tailored for tasks like speaker verification and, in this case, accent classification.
type.quote: The ECAPA-TDNN model has shown state-of-the-art results in speaker verification tasks.

name.justification: Wav2Vec 2.0 is used in its multilingual XLSR form for accent classification, and the model is fine-tuned for the task.
name.quote: We address multilingual accent classification through the ECAPA-TDNN and Wav2Vec 2.0/XLSR architectures.

type.justification: Wav2Vec 2.0/XLSR is an acoustic model designed for self-supervised learning of speech representations.
type.quote: The w2v2-XLSR model is designed to acquire cross-lingual speech representations for 53 languages.

name.justification: Common Voice 7.0 dataset is used for English accent classification in this study.
name.quote: Our recipe fine-tunes either ECAPA-TDNN [7] or w2v2 [3] models (also XLSR) in the accent classification task. Our system follows closely the CommonLanguage recipe available in SpeechBrain. Additionally, we open-source fine-tuned models in the HuggingFace Hub.

name.justification: Common Voice 11.0 dataset is used for German, Spanish, and Italian accent classification in this study.
name.quote: Our model follows closely the CommonLanguage recipe available in SpeechBrain. Additionally, we open-source fine-tuned models for English, Spanish, German, and Italian in the HuggingFace Hub. We also use Common Voice 11.0 for additional languages and accent classification.

name.justification: The SpeechBrain toolkit is used extensively for the experiment setups and recipe implementations in the study.
name.quote: Our aim is to provide insight and guidance for evaluating fine-tuned LAMs in a more inclusive manner... Specifically, in this work, we introduce a simple-to-follow recipe on the SpeechBrain [6] toolkit to perform accent classification based on speech recordings.
